Ecosystem and environmental conditions: • Recruitment: Recent recruitment is accounted for under the model data column and thus was not used for the scoring here.
Assessment data inputs: • Catch reconstruction (landings and discards) is reliable for sablefish, with estimates going back to the early 1900s for hook-and-line and trawl fisheries and the incorporation of foreign landings beginning in the 1960s.
Assessment model fits and structural unc: • Captures changes in productivity through time-varying growth, recruitment deviations, and natural mortality well. However, available data not informative on absolute stock size or productivity at small stock sizes (steepness).

Ecosystem and environmental conditions: • Habitat: The center of gravity of sablefish biomass has shifted approximately 2 degrees northward likely in response to higher recruitment north of 40 N. latitude in recent years.
Assessment data inputs: • A high degree of confidence in the design, and subsequent population inference, for the primary fishery-independent survey (WCGBTS). The survey covers the most recent 20+ years, so is particularly applicable to current management. However, sablefish are found deeper than the limit of survey sampling.
Assessment model fits and structural unc: • Made simplifying assumption of constant natural mortality, implying no variation by sex, life-stage (or age), time, or space.

Ecosystem and environmental conditions: • Prey:  Most available evidence suggests adequate forage for sablefish in 2024 and recent years.
Assessment data inputs: • A recruitment index based on hypothesized environmental-drivers was incorporated into the assessment, informing the most recent 5 years of recruitment strength.
Assessment model fits and structural unc: • Steepness fixed at reasonable value (0.75) given life history and management (reference point) objectives. Recruitment deviations only estimated for the second half of the time series.

Ecosystem and environmental conditions: • Predators: Predation by five main predator groups (California sea lions, sperm whales, porpoises, skates, and fur seal) is unlikely to have changed much in recent years, but there have  been long-term increases in some groups like sea lions.
Assessment data inputs: • Age data is well sampled across the species range for the last 40 years with near continuous sampling from fishery and fishery-independent sources.
Assessment model fits and structural unc: • Loses or gains in biomass are not captured due to transboundary movements (e.g., Canada).

Ecosystem and environmental conditions: • Competitors: Changes in competition are highly uncertain;  we can’t quantitatively determine that euphausiid abundance is limiting for sablefish, but there is some potential for competition by hake and sablefish for prey (euphausiids).
Assessment data inputs: • Age data available beginning at age-0, so some information on recruitment present up through the final data year.
Assessment model fits and structural unc: • No long term trends in recruitment. Estimates of large cohorts are robust across sensitivity runs with little to no retrospective patterns. Recent recruitment informed by environmental index.

Assessment data inputs: • Age data are generally fit well with realistic selectivity assumptions. The WCGBTS fits and tracks the primary dynamics well.
Assessment model fits and structural unc: • Sensitivity runs reasonable and generally produce symmetric changes relative to base model results.

Assessment data inputs: • Time-varying growth incorporated using empirical weight-at-age methods, where annual growth was integrated across latitude according to survey biomass estimates. New estimates of functional maturity were also integrated across latitude to capture spatial differences.
Assessment model fits and structural unc: • Model stability considerably improved, with stable jitters and consistent identifiable parameters at reasonable values across many data and structural model changes.
